The Education (Admission to Schools) Bill will be at Dáil committee stage this evening, I'll be proposing a number of amendments
This Bill is about fairness and making it easier for parents to enrol their children in a school that meets their needs
It will ensure that where a school is not oversubscribed (around 80% of all schools) it must admit all students applying
We are banning waiting lists. This will end the discrimination against parents who move into a new area
We are explicitly banning fees relating to admissions
Schools must publish their admissions policies, including provisions for pupils who decline to participate in religious instruction
All schools will be required to consult with and inform parents where changes are being made to admissions policies
For the first time, we will be explicitly banning discrimination in school admissions
I have set out my preferred option for addressing the role of religion in school admissions this evening
This is a very important, complex issue & I believe my preferred option manages to strike a balance btw fairness & protecting min religions
I believe that it is unfair that children of a certain religion who might live some distance away are given preference over local children
I don’t believe parents, who might otherwise not do so, should feel pressure to baptize their children to gain admission to local school

I'll be launching the Government's #ForeignLanguages Strategy this morning. Aim to put Ireland in the top 10 for the teaching and learning of foreign languages in Europe.
This morning I am launching the Government's Strategy for Foreign Languages in Education 2017-2026
The Strategy Plan sets out a plan to ensure Ireland's place in the top ten countries in Europe for teaching and learning of foreign languages
The delivery of this strategy is a key action in my Action Plan for Education, with the aim of making Ireland's education and training service the best in Europe in a decade
In the context of Brexit and the increasing importance globally of non-English speaking countries, I am taking action to ensure Ireland is well prepared for the challenges that lie ahead.

Once the United Kingdom leaves the EU, Ireland will be one of only two English speaking countries in the Union. Therefore, it is imperative that this Strategy ensures Ireland is prepared for the challenges ahead.
My Foreign Languages Strategy will allow us to maximise our assets, by ensuring our education and training service is well equipped to respond to a changing global environment

(1/2) Under the Foreign Languages Strategy my Department will: - Increase the number of post-primary schools offering two or more foreign languages by 25% - Increase the number of students sitting two languages at Junior Certificate and Leaving Certificate by 25%

(2/2) - Increase the number of students in higher education studying a foreign language at part of their course by 20% - Increase the number of participants in Erasmus+ by 50% - Double the number of foreign language assistants in schools

I have included 100 actions to ensure the success of the strategy, including: - Introduce Mandarin Chinese as a Leaving Certificate subject - Introduce curricular specifications for hertiage speakers for Polish, Lithuanian and Portuguese

- Develop a range of short courses in languages for Junior Cycle - Enhance employer engagement in the development of new trade languages - Increase the opportunities for short-term teacher exchanges for post-primary teachers

I have developed a number of strategies to increase the number of foreign language teachers, these teachers will be key to achieving the best results from the Foreign Languages Strategy these include: - A baseline data collection excercise to understand current supply of teachers

- Research to identify future language needs, with the aim of ensuring provision and uptake in line with those needs. - Indentify teachers who are qualified to teach a foreign language but may not have the opportunity to teach that language in their school.

- Consider the possibility of a post-graduate programme for teachers, with a language, who may be able to learn another language - Explore the potential for alternative, flexible models such as blended learning, cluster learners, and evening/weekend classes

Today I am announcing 3 changes which will have a major impact on how a child accesses their local school
These 3 changes are amendments to the Education (Admissions to School) Bill 2016, which were approved by cabinet yesterday
The first of of these amendments will remove the role of religion in school admissions for virtually all primary schools
As I have said before, I believe that it is unfair that a local child of no religion is passed over in favour of a child of religion, living some distance away for access to their local school
Parents should not feel pressured to baptise their child to get access to their local school

While 90% of our primary schools are of a Catholic ethos, recent figures show that over 20% (and growing) of our parent-age population is non-religious. In addition recent marriage statistics for 2017 show that only approximately 51% of marriages occurred in a Catholic ceremony
The government has approved an amendment that will remove religion as a criterion which can be used in school admissions in over 95% of our primary schools

Now on @morningireland to discuss the same. This is about balance and fairness. I don’t think it’s fair that parents feel pressure to baptise their child to get into their local school when they would not otherwise do so https://t.co/JuG3JBkcuY
Under the proposed new law, there will be a protection to ensure that a child of minority faith can still access a school of their faith
The changes balance the rights of three different groups; minority religion families, catholic families, and non-denominational families
Minority religion families, because of their small size within the overall population, could find it difficult to access schools of their own religious ethos

The exception for minority faith children, is because only 1 out of every 20 of our primary schools are of minority ethos and they need to ensure that children of minority faith can access an education through their ethos, if that is their choice
These changes will only impact oversubscribed primary schools (approx 20%), which are predominately locates in large urban areas.
Schools that are not oversubscribed must continue to accept all applicants, regardless of religion
The second amendment is to provide for Irish medium schools to give priority to Irish speaking children

This amendment will allow Irish medium schools (where it is their policy to do so) to give priority in admission to students who have a reasonable age appropriate level of oral fluency in the Irish language, taking account of any special educational needs a child might have
The last amendment, will give the Minister of Education the power to require a school to open a special class for children with special educational needs, when the NCSE deems it necessary to do so

Today I am announcing that I will introduce a new Online Safety Act to improve online safety and protect our children online. I will be on @MorningIreland @BreakfastNT shortly
New technology is transforming how we work, live and learn. This provides huge opportunities for us all, but it also presents new risks which we have to respond to
I believe that the situation at present where online and social media companies are not subject to any oversight or regulation by the state is no longer sustainable

The Online Safety Act will place new requirements on operators, such as the requirement to operate an Online Safety Code, which would have a number of minimum requirements, such the prohibition of cyber bullying for example
The era of self regulation in this area is over and a new Online Safety Act is necessary
This new legislation will protect our children online and will be overseen by a regulator, an Online Safety Commissioner
An Online Safety Commissioner will be given a number of powers, such as certifying that the Online Safety Codes put in place by operators are fit for purpose
The Commissioner will also be given powers to administer fines for non-compliance and publish whether or not a company has complied, among other very significant powers

The second role of the Online Safety Commissioner would be to apply European Law to video sharing. The new law requires significant changes to the way in which Ireland regulates video sharing platforms
